oai_dc:dc.dc:title: C.A. Haun Parting from his Family before his Execution
Haun, Christopher, illustration
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: George W. Childs, Applegate & Co., Philadelphia
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William G. Brownlow, Sketches of the Rise, Progress, and Decline of Secession; with a Narrative of Personal Adventures Among the Rebels (Philadelphia: George W. Childs, Applegate & Co., 1862), p. 312

This illustration depicts a man in a wagon reaching out for a child, while a weeping woman and another child stand in front of him, and a coachman and team are at the ready. A uniformed man with gun in hand pointing upward stands behind the wagon. Within the drawing at lower right is an artist's credit reading " Richardson-Cox, Sc."

Christopher Alexander Haun was a skilled ceramic potter who lived near Greeneville, Tennessee, in a community called Pottertown. He was one of a group of Union loyalists who destroyed the Lick Creek Bridge on the East Tennessee & Virginia Railroad on the night of November 8-9, 1861. Haun was hanged by Confederate officials in Knoxville on 10 December 1861. He was one of five men executed for their actions disrupting the movement of Confederate troops and supplies into upper East Tennessee. This image appeared on page 312 of William G. Brownlow's Sketches of the Rise, Progress, and Decline of Secession; with a Narrative of Personal Adventures Among the Rebels (Philadelphia: George W. Childs, Applegate & Co., 1862)
